questions.stem: What is the primary goal of a hemorrhage kit in home palliative care?

options.label: A
options.text: To stop the bleeding completely

options.label: B
options.text: To provide comfort and reduce distress during a bleed

options.label: C
options.text: To prepare for emergency transport to hospital

options.label: D
options.text: To document the bleeding event for legal purposes

questions.stem: Which medication is typically included in a hemorrhage kit for sedation?

options.label: A
options.text: Haloperidol

options.label: B
options.text: Midazolam

options.label: C
options.text: Ondansetron

options.label: D
options.text: Dexamethasone

questions.stem: Why are dark-colored towels recommended in a hemorrhage kit?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more absorbent than white towels

options.label: B
options.text: They reduce the visual impact of blood for patient and family

options.label: C
options.text: They are easier to clean after the event

options.label: D
options.text: They are required by home care regulations

questions.stem: When should goals of care regarding hemorrhage be discussed?

options.label: A
options.text: Only after the first bleeding episode

options.label: B
options.text: When hemorrhage is imminent

options.label: C
options.text: Proactively, before a crisis occurs

options.label: D
options.text: After the patient is no longer able to participate

questions.stem: What is the most important first step in a goals of care conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Explaining all treatment options available

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the patient's values and priorities

options.label: C
options.text: Discussing prognosis in detail

options.label: D
options.text: Reviewing the medical chart thoroughly

questions.stem: How should a clinician respond when a patient says they want 'everything done'?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately arrange for aggressive interventions

options.label: B
options.text: Explore what 'everything' means to the patient

options.label: C
options.text: Explain why aggressive treatment isn't recommended

options.label: D
options.text: Document the request and move on

questions.stem: Which statement best reflects a patient-centered approach to care planning?

options.label: A
options.text: 'Based on your condition, I recommend hospice care.'

options.label: B
options.text: 'What matters most to you as we plan your care?'

options.label: C
options.text: 'Your family thinks you should focus on comfort.'

options.label: D
options.text: 'Most patients in your situation choose palliative care.'

questions.stem: When is it appropriate to revisit goals of care?

options.label: A
options.text: Only when the patient requests it

options.label: B
options.text: When there is a significant change in clinical status

options.label: C
options.text: At each scheduled appointment

options.label: D
options.text: Only at the time of initial diagnosis

questions.stem: What is the most common unmet need among family caregivers in palliative care?

options.label: A
options.text: Financial assistance

options.label: B
options.text: Information and communication

options.label: C
options.text: Transportation support

options.label: D
options.text: Meal preparation help

questions.stem: Which sign might indicate caregiver burnout?

options.label: A
options.text: Asking detailed questions about medications

options.label: B
options.text: Expressing frustration or withdrawal from care activities

options.label: C
options.text: Requesting additional home care visits

options.label: D
options.text: Taking notes during clinical discussions

questions.stem: How can healthcare providers best support anticipatory grief in caregivers?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoid discussing death to prevent distress

options.label: B
options.text: Normalize grief reactions and provide space for expression

options.label: C
options.text: Focus only on practical care tasks

options.label: D
options.text: Refer immediately to bereavement services

questions.stem: What should be included in preparing a family for a potential home death?

options.label: A
options.text: Instructions to call 911 immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Information about what to expect and who to call

options.label: C
options.text: Recommendation to transfer to hospital in final days

options.label: D
options.text: Assurance that death will not occur at home
